Credits.Story By: LAWRENCE O'DONNELL JR., PAUL REDFORD & AARON SORKIN

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT - FRIDAY EVENING
Scenes.Description: We see the panel of Supreme Court Judges sitting on the bench. One of them is reading a verdict in front of three public defenders.

Dialogues.Line: Assuming arguendo that the district court erred in allowing the jury to consider non- statutory factors that were vague, overbroad or duplicative in violation of the eighth amendment such error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. The application for a stay of execution of the sentence of death, presented to the Chief Justice and referred by him to the court, is denied. The petition for a writ of certiorary is denied. The petitioner is remanded to the federal facility in Terre Haute, Indiana, to be executed by lethal injection, Monday morning at 12:01 a.m. At the sound of the gavel, we--

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The three public defenders are walking down the hall.

Dialogues.Line: Who's our guy at the White House?
It's over.
Jerry...
It's over.
Who's our guy at the White House?
We don't have a guy at the White House.
I'm saying who can we call right now?
At eight o'clock on a Friday?
Yes.
The switchboard operator.
Jerry, who do we know who's got the ear of the President?
Nobody!
Sam Seaborn. [They all stop walking.]
You know Seaborn?
I used to beat him up in high school.
You're kidding me.
No.
You can call him right now?
Yeah.
He'll take the call?
Let's find out.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE - JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh had just finished work and is about to leave. He tries to tell Donna that he's going to go.

Dialogues.Line: I'm out of here.
You've got to see Sam. Josh turns back and walks the other way. Donna joins him into the HALLWAY.
I'm seeing Sam, and then I'm out of here.
Are you going to behave yourself tonight?
It's a bachelor party.
I'm saying...
I can hold my liquor.
No you can't.
I can drink with the best of them.
You can't drink with any of them, Josh.
I'm in politics, okay. I can drink.
You have a very sensitive system.
I wish you'd stop telling people that. It makes me sound like an idiot.
You're gonna have two drinks and spend the rest of the weekend sleeping it off.
And this is the first time in a long time I've had the opportunity to spend the weekend doing anything but working, is my point.
Are there going to be strippers?
Nah.
Really?
Yeah.
Tell me the truth.
There aren't going to be strippers there. Men don't like that anymore.
Men don't like naked women anymore?
No, we still like naked women a lot. It's looking at them in a room full of your best friends that makes you feel a little...
Sleazy?
Uncomfortable. Josh walks up to Sam as he comes out of the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE. Donna walks away.
Sam.
Hi.
I'm out of here. What do you need? [They start walking.]
[calls to office in general] What do I need?
O'Dwyer.
Yes. I need you to do me a favor.
On O'Dwyer?
His people are calling. They want to know what's going on.
Who's his people?
A campaign manager. A guy named Joey Lucas.
Never heard of him.
Me neither.
What's he like?
I didn't speak with him. I spoke with his assistant.
What's the favor?
I scheduled a meeting for tomorrow with him to try to figure out what's going on.
Aren't you going sailing tomorrow?
Yeah.
Then how are you gonna... [light dawns] Oh, come on!
Ten minutes. They had gone back to the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE.
On a Saturday!
Well, do you have plans?
I was planning on doing nothing.
Ten minutes, fifteen minutes tops.
Sam...
He's going to be very excited to meet with you. Joshua Lyman, Deputy Chief of Staff. He can hear it from the horse's mouth.
What am I supposed to tell him?
On O'Dwyer?
Yeah. Donna walks up.
Tell him the truth.
I don't think so. What else you got?
What time?
10:00 tomorrow morning.
[to Josh] You have to be here at 10:00 tomorrow morning.
We have to be here at 10:00 tomorrow morning.
Why me?
'Cause you work for me.
[pouts] I have things to do tomorrow morning, Josh. It was my Saturday too.
What things?
I have to go shopping.
For what?
Whatever! It's Saturday.
Ten minutes. When it's over I'll buy you some shoes.
[smiles] Really? [leaves]
I'm out of here.
I'm bringing back the Cup, man.
Sam, just stay in the boat this time and I'm a happy guy.
Okay.
Good luck. [walks off]
[shouting after Josh] I've got foul weather gear.
[shouts back] See you later. Bonnie is getting ready to leave. So is Sam. They start to put on their jackets.
Bonnie, I'm done?
You're done.
I'm cutting the cord, Bonnie. I'm gonna be unreachable for the weekend.
Good.
Not taking my pager. [puts it on desk] Not taking my cell phone. [puts it next to pager]
You've earned it!
Out on the ocean blue. Totally cut off from the White House.
It'll be good for you.

[to himself] I'm taking my pager. [sticks it in his coat pocket] Should probably take my cell phone too. [picks it up] No. No. Cutting the cord. [puts it down] Not taking the cell phone. [pulls pager out and puts it on desk] Not taking the pager.
Sam.
Yeah?
You need to relax.
Yeah.
Have a good weekend.
You too. Bonnie leaves. The phone rings as Sam is leaving. He looks at it, then shuts off the light and closes the door behind him. The phone rings some more before Sam comes back in and picks it up.
Sam Seaborn.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. COURTHOUSE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam and BOBBY ZANE, one of the public defenders, are walking through.

Dialogues.Line: Is he guilty?
That's not the point.
Is he guilty?
Sam.
Bobby, is he guilty?
In '94 Justice Blackmun officially went on record...
Bobby!
It was a drug cartel. He killed two kingpins.
You want me to argue it was a public service measure?
Sam, I'm not talking about a couple of schoolgirls.
Blackmun's in support of the death penalty.
I tell you he reversed himself in '94. 'From this day forward,' he said, 'I no longer shall tinker with the machinery of death.'
Yes.
'I feel morally and intellectually obligated simply to concede that the death penalty experiment has failed.'
You don't have to quote Harry Blackmun with me.
You are going to go to the President, and you're gonna tell him he can't run from this one. He's got to consider my client. You're gonna tell him that.
I don't talk to the President that way, Bobby. Nobody talks to the President that way. And I'm gonna tell you not that many people talk to me that way anymore.
I've got a guy 48 hours away from death. You're gonna make this personal?
How long you been with the P.D.'s office?
About two years.
I heard you were at Ross-Lipton.
Yeah, I was.
What happened?
They gave me a partnership and a corner office, Sam. What do you think happened?
The President's very serious about the separation of powers.
Yeah, but so's the Constitution. In Article 2, Section 2 says, 'He shall have the power to grant reprieves and pardons for offenses against the United States.'
Thanks for pointing that out. I'm saying the judicial branch has spoken, so why should...?
Oh, that's what he's going to hide behind?
The President's not hiding behind anything. Right now the President's on Air Force One coming back home from Stockholm.
So when does he land?
Around 9:00 a.m.
That's when you're going to talk to him?
Well, I won't be here tomorrow morning, but I'll ask Toby Ziegler to talk...
Where are you going?
Bobby.
Sam.
I'll pass it up to Toby Ziegler. He'll ask for a few minutes of the President's time, but I have to be honest with you. After a long trip...
He'll talk to the President first thing in the morning?
Well, it's Saturday. I think Toby will probably be at temple first thing in the morning.
What temple?
Bobby.
What temple?
I don't know the name of the temple.
You know where it is?
[caught off guard] I think it's on Delaware.
Thank you. Sam is a little surprised after Bobby quickly walks away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam returns to his office to grab his bag.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo comes out of the Roosevelt Room. Sam sees him behind. They walk together.

Dialogues.Line: Leo.
I thought you left.
I just came back to get my bag.
What's going on?
They denied the appeal.
Simon Cruz.
Yeah.
I thought they were sending it back to the...
Me too.
No, our guy said they were going to send it back to the sixth circuit.
Well they didn't. The denied the appeal five-three.
That's not what was supposed to happen.
We've got the get Mendoza on the Bench.
Come on.
Leo.
If Mendoza was on the bench, they would have lost five-four. So what are we talking about?
The execution is scheduled...
What? They reach LEO'S OFFICE.
The execution is scheduled for 12:01 Monday morning, so the ball's in our court.
I'm not sure the President wants the ball in our court.
Well, that makes two of us.
Have a good weekend.
You're not gonna...
He lands at 9:00 tomorrow morning. I'll let him sleep a little bit then I'll talk it through with him.
I can brief Toby before I leave.
Right.
I'll see you later. [starts to leave]
Sam.
Yeah? [turns back]
Why Monday morning?
What do you mean?
The court denied the appeal. Why isn't he being executed at midnight tonight?
We don't execute people between sundown Friday and sundown Sunday.
Why?
Hard as it is to believe...
[figures it out for himself] You're kidding me.
No.
We don't execute people on the Sabbath.
No.
Well, that's about the most bizarre thing I've ever heard.
Leo, I think you're gonna find as you go through this weekend that there's virtually no part of this discussion that isn't bizarre. I'm gonna go home now. I got to race in the morning. [leaves]
[calls after Sam] Hold on to a rope or something, would you.
Yeah. Sam leaves. The camera closes on Leo.
Damn it.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NORTHWEST LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam goes to sign out. He picks up the pen and thinks. He changes his mind and heads back.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam sets down his bag, pulls a book off the shelf and sits down at his desk. He turns on the light, puts on his glasses and starts reading.

Dialogues.Line: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY SATURDAY, 9:00 A.M. Donna arrives. She puts down her bag and hangs her jacket. She opens the door to JOSH'S OFFICE. She finds Josh lying on the floor in front of his desk in disgustingly dirty clothes, snoring.
Josh. Josh snores.
Josh! Josh, sputtering, wakes up and sits up, blinking. He is very obviously hung over, and has a pair of lacy red panties around his neck.
Hi.
What are you doing?
What?
Did you spend the night here?
No. Just since a couple of hours ago.
The party went to morning?
Yup.
Why didn't you go home?
What?
Why didn't you go home after the party?
I couldn't find my keys, or remember where I lived. [pulls the panties off over his head]
Josh.
I think there might have been strippers there. [gets up]
[yells] Oh my God! Josh shushes her.
What happened to your clothes?
I may have wrinkled my suit.
Josh!
Donna. You... You really want to speak very softly.
How did you get like this?
People were pouring champagne over each other.
And then wrestling in dirt?
I can't remember, but it's certainly not out of the question.
You have a meeting.
Yeah, I know. I'm not, you know. Uh... what was the meeting again?
Joey Lucas about O'Dwyer.
Yes. [puts on his suit jacket.]
Josh.
I'm fine.
You can't wear those clothes. [holds her nose]
I'm fine.
Trust me.
They're the only clothes I got.
I'll find some other clothes.
Fine. [sits in his chair as Donna starts to leave]
Are you going to listen to me from now on?
[under breath] I'm not even listening to you now.
[shouts] I said, are you going to listen...
Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Donna leaves and Josh slumps forward onto his desk.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. ANDREW'S AIR FORCE BASE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo gets out of a limousine. He walks toward Bartlet, C.J. and Charlie as they come off of Air Force One.

Dialogues.Line: C.J., look...
Don't start with me, Mr. President.
I was helping pass the time. I was being entertaining as well as instructive.
I'm back in America now, I have rights. I'm no longer belted down next to the passenger from hell.
[walks up] Welcome back, Mr. President.
Leo! What're you doing here?
I needed a minute, sir. How was the flight?
It was --
Great!

-- gruesome. 'If you'll look out the left side of the cabin, you'll see the fjords.' Then we got a history of the fjords. Then we got a quiz on the fjords. [to Bartlet] Do you have any idea how much I would like to dress you up in lederhosen and drop kick you into the fjords right now?
Aww. You don't know how to have fun when we're traveling... C.J. and Bartlet get into the car.
[quietly to Leo] It was quite a trip. [gets into car]
[under breath] It ain't over yet. He gets into the limousine. C.J. sneezes as they drive off.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Donna walks into Josh's office with bright yellow hip-waders in one hand and a cup in the other.

Dialogues.Line: Josh.
Huh.
Here. [puts foul weather gear on desk]
What's that?
It's Sam's foul weather gear. Drink this. [puts cup on desk]
Coffee?
It's strong. Drink it all. Donna walks out. Josh drinks, gags, and lets the coffee run out of his mouth down the front of his shirt.
Blah.
[comes back in] It's from yesterday, so it might not be hot anymore.
What time is this person coming?
Forty minutes. Put this on. [indicates hip-waders]
I'm not wearing that.
There's a one-hour cleaners on Connecticut.
He's getting here in forty minutes.
Zuzu will do it in half an hour.
Who's Zuzu?
The guy from the dry cleaners, Josh. Change your clothes!
His name is Zuzu?
Change your clothes.
I'll look like the Gorton's fisherman in this thing. [gets up and starts to change]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JEWISH SYNAGOGUE - DAY
Scenes.Description: People sit down as the rabbi starts his sermon. We see Toby in the crowd.

Dialogues.Line: With Passover on the horizon, millions of Jews will gather round Seder tables, will sing our songs and ask our questions. Toby's beeper suddenly goes off. People look at him.
About the stick that beat the dog that bit the cat that ate the kid. Toby checks his beeper, then gets up and works his way out of the row and walks to the back while the rabbi continues.
We'll sing not only to entertain our children but to be reminded by the Haggadah, the simple truth. That violence begets violence. Vengeance is not Jewish. We'll pour ten drops...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SYNAGOGUE ENTRANCEWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Toby gets to the entranceway and pulls out his cell phone, dials.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: The phone rings and Sam answers it.

Dialogues.Line: Sam Seaborn.
What do you want?
How ya doing?
Sam, I'm at temple right now.
Yeah, by any chance is your rabbi giving a sermon on capital punishment?
What?
Is your rabbi giving a sermon on capital punishment? Toby puts his cell phone to his shoulder and listens to the rabbi.
No matter how deep our desire to witness the sufferings of our enemies, we are commanded to relocate our humanity. Vengeance is not Jewish. We are commanded to relocate...
[puts the phone back to his ear] Yeah, he is. How did you know that?
I'll explain it to you when you get over here.
Why am I coming over there?
The appeal was denied.

All right, I'm on my way. Toby puts his phone away. Just as we hear the rabbi say 'quietly,' he leans slightly against a stack of folded metal chairs and then watches in horror as they slide to the floor in a horrendous crash.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: A man and a woman burst in, to find Josh in an undershirt and the hip-waders. JOEY LUCAS, a deaf campaign manager is signing and her assistant, KENNY THURMAN is translating.

Dialogues.Line: Are you the unmitigated jackass who has the DNC choking off funding for the O'Dwyer campaign in the California forty-sixth?
[bleary] What is God's name is happening right now?
I'm Joey Lucas.
[to Kenny] You're Joey Lucas? Kenny looks at Joey, then back at Josh.
No, I'm Joey Lucas.
Help me, 'cause I... I don't...
[yells] You idiot. I'm. Joey. Lucas.
Ah. [pause] Ah, okay. I'm Josh Lyman.
I know who you are.
You're Joey Lucas.
What were you expecting?
A man.
I'm a woman.
You're O'Dwyer's campaign manager?
Yes, and I have three sources, two at the DNC... Josh stands up.
What the hell are you wearing?
Me?
Yes.

[looks down at himself] I was... I uh... I... I spilt some things on my clothes. Tell you what, let's... let's just take a deep breath for a second while I try and remember, you know, where I am right now. Josh walks around the desk, obviously to within smelling distance of Joey, who covers her nose.
Are you drunk?
I have a very delicate system.
Okay, look, I'm totally serious about this. I'm trying to get a guy elected to Congress. It's gonna be a very tight race and I want to know why the White House is screwing around with me.
[comes to the door, holding Josh's suit] Excuse me.
Thank God.
What's going on?
[to Joey] This is my assistant, Donna Moss. Donna, Joey Lucas.
[to Joey] Hi.
I'm just going to go... I... I... I'm... I'm gonna go change my clothes. I'll... I'll be right back. Josh and Donna walk out to the HALLWAY.
Took you long enough.
I got stuck at Dupont Circle again.
You have any idea how dumb I looked in there?
So Joey Lucas is a woman.
Yes.
And she's deaf.
Yes.
Cool.
Give me those. He takes the clothes and heads into a room while Donna stays outside.
You need to go see Sam.
What's Sam doing here?
He told me to tell you the appeal was denied.
What are you talking about?
All he said was 'The appeal was denied.'
[nickel drops] Oh, man. Make sure they're going to be okay in there. This might take a few minutes.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam and Mandy are doing research. Toby is just standing there, looking at Sam.

Dialogues.Line: Are you saying my rabbi wrote a sermon just for me?
Yeah.
How did he know what was going on here?
One of the public defenders, guy named Bobby Zane...
One of the public defenders spoke to my rabbi?
Yeah.
How did he know where I go to temple? How did he know I even go to temple?
[comes in, tucking in his shirt] I thought they were sending it back to the sixth circuit.
I thought so too.
Where's the President?
He's in the residence.
Are we getting a briefing from Justice?
He'll be here in a minute.
When's the execution?
Sunday, 12:01.
Monday, 12:01.
Minute after midnight tomorrow.
Lethal injection?
Yeah.
[looks at Josh in disgust] Josh, you sleep in a dumpster last night?
Possibly. [to Sam] Hey, why aren't you sailing right now?
I stayed.
Is there any evidence that capital punishment serves as a deterrent?
Speculative evidence at best.
What are the stats on federal executions and the President stepping in?
'63 was the last execution.
Who was the last President to commute the sentence?
Lincoln.
Abraham?
No, Bert Lincoln. Mandy, what are you-?
I'm asking. I'm surprised.
I don't want a debate on the death penalty. Let's get some stuff together and get ready for the President.
I'm gonna start working with C.J. [leaves]
I gotta get back to... [starts to leave] Oh... By the way, Sam. Joey Lucas is waiting for me in my office right now.
Well, what's he like?
Well, for a campaign manager, he's got very nice legs.
He's a woman?
Yes. He is. He's also deaf. And very pissed. Be right back. [leaves]
[looking pissed] Sam.
You know there's room to give the President some judicial cover if he wants to commute.
Sam.
This guy was convicted of three murders by a Mexican court. Does that matter to us? During the penalty phase, the trial judge let the prosecutor introduce the evidence of the Mexican convictions.
I know.
Well, the Mexican courts are ridiculous, Toby. That never should have...
How did the public defender know I was at that temple?
I'm saying, this guy didn't have the world's greatest legal council.
How did he know where I was going to be?
I told him.
You told him.
Yeah.
Sam, what're you doing giving out that kind of information-
I know. I don't know. Right at that moment it seemed like what I should do.
He's not going to commute the sentence, Sam.
We don't know what the President's gonna do.
It seemed like what you should do?
Yeah.
Okay. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is dressing up. Leo is briefing him.

Dialogues.Line: So, anyway, he was tried and found guilty four years ago in the district court in Michigan. And the sixth circuit turned down his appeal. The Supreme Court gave him a stay, heard the case, turned him down five-three.
We got to get Mendoza on the bench.
Well, that's Monday's problem. Your problem's today.
Why is it my problem at all?
As opposed to who?
The governor of Michigan.
Oh, you mean, why isn't it a state crime.
Yeah.
It was prosecuted by the U.S. Attorney under the '88 drug kingpin law that was modified into the '94 omnibus crime bill.
Which allows for the death penalty in certain drug related homicides.
Well, basically. The deputy AG's office is putting together a briefing for you.
How long?
About an hour.
Okay, I'll wait for that then.
Yeah.
I'm gonna want to see our people over the next few days.
Everyone's here now or on their way.
I'm not going to be very good at this, Leo.
Well, you'll be joining a pretty big club, Mr. President.
Yeah. [calls] Charlie!
I'll call you when the guys have put something together.
Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. [leaves]
[comes in] Yes sir.

Charlie, there's a priest in Hanover. His name is Thomas Cavanaugh. He's at the Immaculate Heart of Mary. I'd like to arrange to have him come down and spend some time with me this weekend. Very important that the White House not pay for this. This is my nickel.
Yes sir.
And I'm gonna want to... [stops]
I'm sorry, sir?
No. No, never mind. [pause] Yeah. I'm gonna want to talk to the Pope.
Yes sir.
Charlie.
Yes sir.
[gets up and walks over to Charlie] I'm gonna ask you a question. And this is one of those times that it's okay to tell me I've stepped over the line, and I should shut my mouth, okay.
Okay.
What happened to the guy who shot your mother?
They haven't found him yet sir.
If they did, would you wanna see him executed? Charlie just looks at him.
Killing a police officer's a capital crime. I figured you must have thought about it.
Yes sir.
And?
I wouldn't want to see him executed, Mr. President -- Bartlet nods.
-- I'd wanna do it myself.
[looks thoughtful] Yeah.
I'll get the ball rolling on these arrangements.
Thank you, Charlie.
Thank you, Mr. President. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh is back in his meeting.

Dialogues.Line: I'm running a campaign against a Conservative Republican who's held his seat for over thirty years. He opposed gay rights, abortion, gun control, and raising the minimum wage. And supports government sponsored prayer in the schools and amending the Bill of Rights to prohibit burning an American flag. Now for the first time in three decades, we have a chance to beat him. Why are you telling the DNC to cut down my funding?
Because you have a chance to beat him.
Excuse me?
We've been watching your campaign. You're doing way too well.
Are you deranged?
He's a preposterous figure. We want to keep him right where he is.
You mean you want to keep him on as a poster boy for the Radical Right?
Joey, every time he comes out with one of his declarations about brown people crossing the border, the DNC slaps it into a direct mail campaign, and he's good for two or three million dollars.
I want to speak to the President.
[laughs] No problem.
I'm perfectly serious.
The President doesn't take meetings on this level. I don't even take meetings on this level!
What level is that?
Joey. [walks to the door]
You can be afraid of me, pal. I can create problems for you, you've never even heard of.
I'm not hearing a lot of party loyalty from you here, Joey.
Well, maybe if your head wasn't so far up your...
Hey!
I want to speak to the President!
[shouting] Hey, Lunatic Lady! Trust me when I tell you that there's absolutely no way that you are going to see the President!
[walks up] Hey, Josh.
Hello, Mr. President. Welcome back.
How are you?
Well, I'd like this day to be over pretty bad.
Who are your friends?
Uh, this is Joey Lucas.
[to Joey] How are you?
Honored to meet you, Mr. President.
Thank you.
[indicates Kenny] And this is Kenny... somebody.
Hi, Kenny.
Thurman.
We were just finishing up.
I was just wandering the halls and thinking.
Why don't you let me show these people off and, uh, I can wander the halls with you.
[to Joey] You ever seen the White House?
No sir.
Let's take a walk.
Sir.
Come on. Joey looks triumphant as she follows Bartlet out the office.
Yes sir.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. and Carol are walking through the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE towards C.J.'S

Dialogues.Line: Carol. Good. I need biographical information on Simon Cruz.
Is it C-R-U-Z?
I don't know.
What kind of biographical information?
Gonna need to know how to spell his name for sure. They head down the hall as the camera follows Bartlet and Joey, who are trailed by Josh and Kenny.
Do you read lips?
Yes sir.
Joey?
Yes sir.
Is that short for Joanne?
Josephine.
And your last name is Lucas?
Yes sir.
Is that Polish?
Dutch.
Protestant?
Quaker. They walk into THE OVAL OFFICE. Joey is completely in awe.
Well, this is the Oval Office. Come in, please. Sit down. He sits on chair, with Joey and Kenny on the opposite couch. Josh stands by the door.
Well, where did you go to school?
UCLA and Stanford.
There's a guy named Simon Cruz on death row. He's going to be executed in about 36 hours. What do you think I should do?
[thinks] Stay the execution.
Why?
Because the state shouldn't kill people.
He was found guilty of a double murder and drug trafficking.
Send him to prison.
You're against capital punishment.
Yes sir.
Did you study St. Augustine at Stanford?
Yes sir.
Thomas Aquinas?
Yes sir.
Two pretty smart guys, right?
Yes sir.
They believed in that part of the Old Testament which said, 'Who sheddeth a man's blood by man shall his blood be shed.'
And Immanuel Kant said that the death penalty is a categorical imperative. But, Mr. President, those writings are from other centuries.
I've got a Harris poll says seventy-one percent of the American people support capital punishment.
That's a political problem.
I'm a politician.
Yes sir. Bartlet looks up at Josh, who gets the idea.
Thank you, Mr. President. We should... [gestures to the door] Everyone stands. Bartlet turns to walk to his desk, but Joey reaches out to get his attention.
Excuse me.
Mr. President, I'm here 'cause I'm running a campaign for Bill O'Dwyer, who's running...
In the California forty-sixth?
Yes sir.
O'Dwyer's an empty shirt.
Sir?

I don't like guys who run for congress because they think it's a great gig. Find yourself a live one and I'll get interested. In the meantime, the devil you know beats the devil you don't. And I like the devil I got.
But, sir...
Josh will take care of you from here. Joey and Kenny pass Josh as they leave the room and continue walking.
We're going back to the hotel.
It was nice meeting you.
[to Joey] Nice to meet you.
That was me saying that.
[to Joey] You didn't have a good time meeting me? Joey gives him the 'universal sign.'
You know what, I actually know that sign. Joey spells out something else and leaves, followed by Kenny.
Don't know that one, but I can probably guess.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JEWISH SYNAGOGUE - DAY
Scenes.Description: SUNDAY MORNING, 9:10 A.M. A singer is walking down the aisle in the synagogue with her accompanist.

Dialogues.Line: I just want to go through this piece a few times. The camera moves to RABBI GLASSMAN, who is sitting in a pew. Toby walks up from behind him.
Rabbi Glassman.
Toby. I didn't hear you, which is fairly unusual.
[chuckles] Yeah. [sits on a pew behind the rabbi]
You missed the end of my sermon yesterday.
Yeah, well, I had to go back to my office and I think you know why.

A lawyer named Bobby Zane called me Friday night. He told me what was happening. He asked if I had any influence in Toby Ziegler. I told him clearly he hadn't spent any time with Toby Ziegler. The singer starts her song in the background.
Um? [gestures to singer]
Oh. I'm having a funeral service in the morning. She's practicing a piece.
That's funny.
What?
I never imagined the practicing.
Day and night.
Rabbi. You - and Bobby Zane - what were you expecting of me when you gave your sermon yesterday?
Well, I suppose it was some hope you might take the Sabbath day to consider your position.
As Communications Director, uh, I'm a counselor to the President to be sure. But my role in these situations is generally... I create a public face for what... I don't influence policy.
Of course you do.
You want me to go into the Oval Office and say, 'Vengeance is not Jewish'?
[shrugs] Why not?
Well, for one thing, neither is the President!
You can say all you want about the Catholic Church, but their position on life is unimpeachable. No abortion, no death penalty.
Look, I... I spent the day...
You spent the day hoping the President wouldn't call the Pope.
You're damn right. I did.
If he had commuted the sentence after talking to the Pope, the worst fears of every non-Catholic who voted for him would be realized. Both chuckle.
Congratulations, Rabbi Glassman, you may now join the White House communications staff.
Look, Toby, you look like you're having a long weekend. I appreciate the courtesy of you stopping by.
Yeah, well, you're welcome. [Both get up.] The Torah doesn't prohibit capital punishment.
No.
It says, 'An eye for an eye.'

You know what it also says? It says a rebellious child can be brought to the city gates and stoned to death. It says homosexuality is an abomination and punishable by death. It says men can be polygamous and slavery is acceptable. For all I know, that thinking reflected the best wisdom of its time, but it's just plain wrong by any modern standard. Society has a right to protect itself, but it doesn't have a right to be vengeful. It has a right to punish, but it doesn't have to kill.
You know what I think? I think you knew I was coming back here. And I think you put her there on purpose. [gestures to singer]
She's our communications director.
[chuckles] Yeah. Well, anyway.
Shalom, Toby.
Shalom, Rabbi. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is sitting in her office, looking at a picture of three children playing. She is obviously bothered by something. Mandy comes in.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah.
You have everything you need?
Yeah.
I mean for a briefing.
I have his biographical information. His mother's name is Sophia. Sophia.
You're gonna need more than that.
I have more than that.
Okay. [starts to leave]

You know, I have no position on capital punishment. I try to get worked up about it, it seems like I should. But the truth is, I honestly don't care if Simon Cruz lives or dies. And I suppose if it brings some measure of comfort to the families of the victims, then why the hell not.
That's valid.
So, here's my job tonight. If this thing happens. [opens a folder, puts on glasses and starts to read] 'At 12:01, he'll get the injection...'

No, I'm saying, I'm reading it, right here. 'The first sign of death will be his hands twitching. After sixty seconds, he'll strain against the straps, his head will have snapped back violently, and after ninety seconds he'll be in convulsions. At 12:04, he'll be pronounced dead.'
He killed two people, probably more. I'm sorry. I don't get worked up over it.

Me neither. That's what I'm saying, me neither. Except... at 12:04, 'cause that's when the warden calls me. That's my job tonight. I have to go in and tell the President that Simon Cruz is dead and we're the ones who killed him. So... [pause] I just wish I didn't know his mother's name was Sophia, is all I'm saying.
[beat] Okay. Mandy leaves. C.J. continues to stare into space, looking even more upset.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: SUNDAY, 6:15 P.M. Bartlet is sitting at his desk, reading. Nancy comes in.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. President, Toby's here.
Okay.
[comes in] Good afternoon, sir. Welcome back.
Thank you.
How was your trip?
Fine. What do you need?
I had a strange experience this weekend. One of the P.D.s on the Cruz case, I guess trying the things you do when you're desperate, he went and spoke to my rabbi.
Jewish law doesn't prohibit...
I know.
The commandment does not say, 'Thou shalt not kill.' It says, 'Thou shalt not murder.'

I know. But the fact is that, even two thousand years ago, the rabbis of the Talmud couldn't... [tries to find the right word] ...stomach it. I mean, they weren't about to rewrite the Torah, but they came up with another way. They came up with legal restrictions, which make our criminal justice system look... They made it impossible for the state... to punish someone by killing them.
We make it very hard to kill anybody in this country, Toby.
It should be impossible.
But it's not.
But it should be. They just stare at each other until Leo comes in.
Hey.
Hey. What's going on?
Toby went to Shul. Leo looks back and forth between Bartlet and Toby.
Yeah. Thank you, Mr. President. [leaves]
[sits in front of Bartlet] Japan opened huge.
Yeah.
Up two cents against the Yen.
I commute this guy, for no particular reason other than I don't like the death penalty...
I know.
And the next President sees it in a different way. I've laid track to all kinds of... The next guy is gonna have eighth amendment problems up the ass.
Well, if that's the only thing that's stopping you...
We cannot execute some people and not execute others depending on the mood of the Oval Office. It's cruel and unusual.
If that's the only thing stopping you, then I'll say this for the first time in your Presidency... Let that be the next guy's problem. There's a knock at the door, then Nancy sticks her head in.
Sir. Sam Seaborn?
Okay. Give me a minute please, Nancy. [looks at Leo and shakes his head]
I'll take care of it.
Thank you.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam and Charlie are just outside the Oval Office.

Dialogues.Line: The U.S. is one of five countries on earth that puts to death people who're under the age of 18 when they committed a crime.
Nigeria.
Pakistan.
Saudi Arabia and Iran?
Yeah. So, that's a list we definitely want to be on.
[comes out of the Oval Office] Sam.
Leo, I put my notes together. I...
Walk with me.
Actually, I was hoping to see the President.
You're not going to see the President, Sam.
Leo.
He's done.
We have six hours...
He's done. They head off walking into the HALLWAY.
Leo, it's not an impossible sell.
I've lived longer than you, Sam...
Leo.
[shouts] He's done, and I gotta tell you, Sam, this was bungled. We were totally unprepared for this.
What the hell are you...?
We were caught in the headlights... This thing was supposed to go back to the sixth circuit. And I don't know how it happened...
[shouts] What are you talking about, prepared? The court sat. What would you have done differently? [They stop walking.]
I'd have...
What would you have done different? You'd have kept the President out of the country another two days?
[quietly] Yes.
Leo, there are times when we are absolutely nowhere. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HOTEL BAR - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh is sitting at the bar in a hotel. Joey and Kenny come in to meet him.

Dialogues.Line: Hello. [to Kenny] Hi.
Hi.
[to Joey] Thank you for meeting me.
Our flight's in one hour.
Aren't you impressed that I was able to track you down?
Was it hard?
It was very hard. I had to have my assistant call your office in California. Joey looks disgusted.
It's funny, when I say it out loud like that, it doesn't sound that impressive.
Do you make me meet you here so you could do more jokes?

[gets serious] No, I came at the request of the President. He wanted you to know that he felt that he was rude to you in the Oval Office yesterday. He apologizes if he was abrupt about your problem and while the tightening of your funding was political strategy on our part, he honestly feels that your candidate is a schmuck who gives liberalism a bad name. Joey thinks about this, and then smiles.
Yeah, I think so too.
[with a big grin] I know you do. Why are you working for him?
I'm a professional political operative. I need to work. I mean, it's not exactly like there's a seller's market for deaf campaign managers.
I'd imagine. He also wanted me to tell you that he meant what he said. Come up with a live one and we'll get interested in a hurry. [puts money on the bar for his drink]
Did he have any suggestions?
As a matter of fact, he did.
Who?
[whispers] You. Joey looks shocked.
You guys have a nice flight back. Joey looks absolutely stunned as she watches him go.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: SUNDAY, 11:57 P.M. Bartlet is standing at the window in the Oval Office. He is looking out at the falling snow and holding a rosary. Charlie comes in.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. President? [beat] Excuse me, Mr. President?
Yeah.
Father Cavanaugh.
Thank you. He walks to the door. FATHER THOMAS CAVANAUGH enters.
Tom.
Mr. President. [They hug.]
Thank you, Charlie. Charlie leaves.
Thanks for coming all this way down.
It was no trouble. I'm just sorry I couldn't get here until now.
Yeah, it seems like a wasted trip.
Oh. I can see the Oval Office.
This is it. They walk farther into the room.
Show me around the room.
You're looking at the room.
Well, uh, where's the red phone?
We don't use the red phone anymore.
Well, how do you talk to the Kremlin?
I tell Mrs. Landingham I want to talk to the Kremlin. Would you like a drink?
No. No thanks. [pause] I don't know how to address you. Would you prefer Jed or Mr. President?
To be honest, I prefer Mr. President.
That's fine.
You understand why, right?
Do I need to know why?
It's not ego.
I didn't think it was.
There are certain decisions I have to make while I'm in this room. Do I send troops into harm's way? Which fatal disease gets the most research money?
Sure.
It's helpful in those situations not to think of yourself as the man but as the office.
Then Mr. President it is.
I want you to know that I had a number of people on my staff search for a reason the public would find palatable to commute the sentence. A technicality. Any evidence of racism.
So your staff spent the weekend looking for a way out.
Yeah.
Like the kid in right field who doesn't want the ball to get hit to him. They sit down.
I'm the leader of a democracy, Tom. Seventy-one percent of the people support capital punishment. People have spoken. The courts have spoken.
Did you call the Pope?
Yeah.
And how do you do that?
[upset] Oh, for crying out loud, Tom. I open my mouth and say, 'Somebody get me the Pope.'
No, I'm sorry, Mr. President, but I was thinking... You're just this kid from my parish and now you're calling the Pope.
Anyway. I looked for a way out, I really did.
''Vengeance is mine,' sayeth the Lord.' You know what that means? God is the only one who gets to kill people.
I know.
That was your way out.
I know.
Did you pray?
I did, Tom. I know it's hard to believe, but I prayed for wisdom.
And none came?
[shakes his head] It never has. And I'm a little pissed off about that. He looks at his watch, which says it's a few seconds before midnight. It hits him hard.
[dead serious] I'm not kidding.

You know, you remind me of the man that lived by the river. He heard a radio report that the river was going to rush up and flood the town. And that all the residents should evacuate their homes. But the man said, 'I'm religious. I pray. God loves me. God will save me.' The waters rose up. A guy in a row boat came along and he shouted, 'Hey, hey you! You in there. The town is flooding. Let me take you to safety.' But the man shouted back, 'I'm religious. I pray. God loves me. God will save me.' A helicopter was hovering overhead. And a guy with a megaphone shouted, 'Hey you, you down there. The town is flooding. Let me drop this ladder and I'll take you to safety.' But the man shouted back that he was religious, that he prayed, that God loved him and that God will take him to safety. Well... the man drowned. And standing at the gates of St. Peter, he demanded an audience with God. 'Lord,' he said, 'I'm a religious man, I pray. I thought you loved me. Why did this happen?' God said, 'I sent you a radio report, a helicopter, and a guy in a rowboat. What the hell are you doing here?' He pauses. Bartlet looks very upset.
He sent you a priest, a rabbi, and a Quaker, Mr. President. Not to mention his son, Jesus Christ. What do you want from him? There is a knock on the door.
Excuse me. C.J. comes in, hands Bartlet a note, and leaves. Bartlet reads the note, and then crumples it up as he goes to lean on the desk. He looks exceedingly troubled.
Jed. Would you like me to hear your confession?
Yes, please. Father Cavanaugh pulls out his stole and puts it on. The President kneels beside him, over the Presidential seal. He performs the sign of the cross.
Bless me, Father, for I have sinned...

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END CREDITS.
